db:abstract.db:para: Securing the CoAP client and using it with a Qt Quick user interface.

db:article.db:para: Quick Secure CoAP Client demonstrates how to create a secure CoAP client and use it in a Qt Quick application.

db:note.db:para: Qt CoAP does not provide a QML API in its current version. However, you can make the C++ classes of the module available to QML as it is shown in the example.

db:section.db:title: Running the Example
db:section.db:para: To run the example from Qt Creator, open the Welcome mode and select the example from Examples. For more information, visit Building and Running an Example.

To run the example application, you first need to set up a secure CoAP server. You can run the example with any secure CoAP server supporting one of the pre-shared key (PSK) or certificate authentication modes. For more information about setting up a secure CoAP server, see Setting Up a Secure CoAP Server.

db:section.db:title: Exposing C++ Classes to QML
db:section.db:para: In this example, you need to expose the QCoapClient class and the QtCoap namespace to QML. To achieve this, create a custom wrapper class and use the special registration macros.

Create the QmlCoapSecureClient class as a wrapper around QCoapClient. This class also holds the selected security mode and security configuration parameters. Use the Q_INVOKABLE macro to expose several methods to QML. Also use the QML_NAMED_ELEMENT macro to register the class in QML as CoapSecureClient.

db:section.db:title: Adjusting Build Files
db:section.db:para: To make the custom types available from QML, update the build system files accordingly.

db:section.db:title: CMake
db:section.db:para: For a CMake-based build, add the following to the CMakeLists.txt:
db:section.db:programlisting: qt_add_qml_module(quicksecureclient URI CoapSecureClientModule SOURCES qmlcoapsecureclient.cpp qmlcoapsecureclient.h QML_FILES FilePicker.qml Main.qml )

db:section.db:title: qmake
db:section.db:para: For a qmake build, modify the quicksecureclient.pro file in the following way:
db:section.db:programlisting:
CONFIG += qmltypes QML_IMPORT_NAME = CoapSecureClientModule QML_IMPORT_MAJOR_VERSION = 1 ... qml_resources.files = \ qmldir \ FilePicker.qml \ Main.qml
qml_resources.prefix = /qt/qml/CoapSecureClientModule
RESOURCES += qml_resources

db:section.db:title: Using New QML Types
db:section.db:para: Now, when the C++ classes are properly exposed to QML, you can use the new types.

db:section.db:title: Creating the Client
db:section.db:para: CoapSecureClient is instantiated from the Main.qml file. It handles the QmlCoapSecureClient::finished() signal and updates the UI accordingly:

The instance of QCoapClient is created when the user selects or changes the security mode in the UI. The QmlCoapSecureClient::setSecurityMode() method is invoked from the QML code, when one of the security modes is selected:
On the C++ side, this method creates a QCoapClient and connects to its finished() and error() signals. The class handles both signals internally, and forwards them to the new finished() signal.

db:section.db:title: Sending a Request
db:section.db:para: Click the Send Request button to set the security configuration based on the selected security mode and send a GET request:
There are two overloads for the setSecurityConfiguration method.
The overload for the PSK mode simply sets the client identity and the pre-shared key:
And the overload for X.509 certificates reads the certificate files and the private key and sets the security configuration:
After setting the security configuration, the sendGetRequest method sets the request URL and sends a GET request:

When sending the first request, a handshake with the CoAP server is performed. After the handshake is successfully done, all the subsequent messages are encrypted, and changing the security configuration after a successful handshake won't have any effect. If you want to change it, or change the host, you need to disconnect first.
This will abort the handshake and close the open sockets.

db:section.db:title: Setting Up a Secure CoAP Server
db:section.db:para: To run this example, you need to have a secure CoAP server supporting either PSK or Certificate modes (or both). You have the following options:

db:listitem.db:para: Manually build and run a secure CoAP server using, for example, libcoap, Californium, FreeCoAP, or any other CoAP library which supports DTLS.

Use the ready Docker images available at Docker Hub, which build and run the secure CoAP servers suitable for our example. The steps required for using the docker-based CoAP servers are described below.

db:section.db:title: Setting Up a Server For PSK Mode
db:section.db:para: The following command pulls the docker container for a secure CoAP server based on Californium plugtest (which is not secure by default) from the Docker Hub and starts it:
db:section.db:programlisting: docker run --name coap-test-server -d --rm -p 5683:5683/udp -p 5684:5684/udp tqtc/coap-californium-test-server:3.8.0
db:section.db:para: The CoAP test server will be reachable on ports 5683 (non-secure) and 5684 (secure). For instructions on retrieving the IP address see Getting The IP Address.
To run the example with this server, you need to set the pre-shared key to secretPSK and the identity to Client_identity.

db:section.db:title: Setting Up a Server For Certificate Mode
db:section.db:para: The docker image of the secure server using authentication with X.509 certificates is based on the time server example from the FreeCoAP library. The following command pulls the container from Docker Hub and starts it:
db:section.db:programlisting: docker run --name coap-time-server -d --rm -p 5684:5684/udp tqtc/coap-secure-time-server:freecoap
db:section.db:para: For instructions on retrieving the IP address see Getting The IP Address. The CoAP test server will be reachable by the retrieved IP address on port 5684 and resource path /time.

To run the example with this server, you need to specify the certificate files required by the server. They are located in the docker container, under /root/certs directory. To copy them to a local directory, use the following command:
db:section.db:programlisting: docker cp <container_id>:/root/certs <local_directory_path>
db:section.db:para: For example:
db:section.db:programlisting: $ docker cp 5e46502df88f:/root/certs ~/
db:section.db:para: The instructions for getting the container ID are described below.

db:section.db:title: Getting The IP Address
db:section.db:para: To find out the IP address of a docker container, first retrieve the container ID by running the docker ps command, which will output something like:
db:section.db:programlisting: $ docker ps CONTAINER ID IMAGE 5e46502df88f tqtc/coap-californium-test-server:3.8.0
db:section.db:para: Then you can obtain the IP address with the following command:
db:section.db:programlisting: docker inspect <container_id> | grep IPAddress
db:section.db:para: For example:
db:section.db:programlisting: $ docker inspect 5e46502df88f | grep IPAddress ... "IPAddress": "172.17.0.2", ...

db:section.db:title: Terminating a Docker Container
db:section.db:para: To terminate a docker container after usage, use the following command:
db:section.db:programlisting: docker stop <container_id>
db:section.db:para: The <container_id> here is the same as retrieved by the docker ps command.
